answers: The University of Florida does not provide specific information in the context given about who coordinates the university's response to student emergencies and crises. However, there are several resources mentioned that students can utilize in case of emergencies or crises, such as Student Legal Services, Passport Services, and the Alachua County Library District. Additionally, the University of Florida has an Emergency Management department that is responsible for coordinating the university's response to emergencies and crises. More information about their services and resources can be found on their website: https://emergency.ufl.edu/

Visitors to the University of Florida can expect to experience an informative and engaging walking tour of the campus during their visit. The Welcome Center, maintained by the Office of Admissions, provides weekday and Saturday information sessions and walking tours. During the tour, visitors will have the opportunity to learn about the various academic colleges, residence halls, and campus facilities. They will also get a sense of the campus culture and student life at UF. Additionally, visitors may be able to see some of the beautiful gardens and landmarks on campus. Overall, the walking tour aims to give visitors a comprehensive understanding of what it's like to be a student at the University of Florida.

Here are the important deadlines for submitting application materials to the University of Florida (UF) Admissions for prospective freshmen in the 2023-24 academic year, based on the context provided:

    Application Opens: August 8, 2023
    Application Due: November 1, 2023 (priority applicant round)
    Student Self-Reported Academic Record (SSAR) Due: November 15, 2023
    Submit Official Test Scores: December 1, 2023
    Freshman Admissions Decisions: February 23, 2024
    Confirm Enrollment: May 1, 2024
    Send Official Transcripts: July 15, 2024

It's important to note that applications received after the priority deadline of November 1, 2023, will be reviewed on a space-available basis, with a final deadline of March 1, 2024. Additionally, if your test scores or transcripts are not received by the respective deadlines, your application will be moved into the space-available applicant pool.
The deadline for prospective freshmen to submit their official transcripts in order to finalize their enrollment at UF for the 2023-24 academic year is July 15.

Parents of dependent undergraduate students at the University of Florida can apply for educational loans through the Federal Direct PLUS loan program by visiting the Student Financial Aid (SFA) website at http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/programs/loans/. The application process involves completing the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) and meeting the enrollment requirements of at least half-time enrollment and a 2.0 GPA for their student. Once the student has been admitted to UF and the FAFSA has been processed, parents can apply for the Federal Direct PLUS loan by following the instructions provided on the SFA website. The website also includes additional information about the loan program, including loan limits, interest rates, and repayment options.

Users can find the available financial aid item types disbursed out of a specific department in the Student Information System by navigating to the Item Types report under the Student Financials section, and searching for the department's DeptFlex value in the ChartField Starts with textbox. Note that users need the UF_ER_SA_Student_Financials security role to access this report.

The Division of Student Life at the University of Florida offers various facilities and services to enhance the student experience. Some of these include:

    Welcome Center: Located next to the Reitz Union, the Welcome Center is maintained by the Office of Admissions and provides weekday and Saturday information sessions and campus tours.
    Student Services: The Division of Student Life oversees various student services such as the Career Connections Center, Center for Inclusion & Multicultural Engagement, Counseling and Wellness Center, Disability Resource Center, Housing and Residence Life, Machen Florida Opportunity Scholars Program, Off Campus Life, Recreational Sports, Student Activities & Involvement, Student Government Advising & Operations, Sorority & Fraternity Life, and Student Legal Services.
    Campus Facilities: Some of the campus facilities include Newell Hall, Reitz Student Union, and Ben Hill Griffin Stadium.
    Disability Resource Center: Provides support services, assistive technology, student involvement opportunities, events, scholarships, and more for students with disabilities.
    Florida Fresh Dining: The official food service provider for the university offers several meal plans.
    GatorLink, GatorOne Card, and UFID: These are unique identifiers for students, providing access to various university services and online resources.
    Housing and Residence Life: Offers on-campus housing for students and helps them get involved, build connections, and succeed in their academic and personal lives.
    Student Financial Aid and Scholarships: Administers financial aid programs, including grants and scholarships, based on financial need or academic performance.

For more information on these facilities and services, students can visit the provided links or contact the respective offices.

The University of Florida Police Department (UFPD) provides various services to ensure campus safety and security for students, faculty, staff, and campus visitors. These services include:

    Uniformed Patrol Division: Highly trained campus law enforcement professionals who patrol the UF campus and its surrounding properties 24 hours a day, equipped with contemporary crime-fighting techniques and tools.
    Criminal Investigations Division: Employs highly trained detectives to investigate any reported crime on campus.
    Community Services Division: Provides information and resources on personal and property protection through classes, programs, and documents.
    Emergency Response Team: Responds to critical incidents and maintains a high level of readiness to protect the campus community.
    Student Nighttime Auxiliary Patrol (SNAP): Provides alternative transportation services, including a free nighttime shuttle van and on-demand service.
    Parking Services: Manages student parking passes and parking enforcement on campus.
    Emergency Notification System: Alerts the campus community of potential threats or emergencies through various communication channels.
    Crime Prevention and Safety Education: Offers workshops, seminars, and educational materials to help prevent crime and promote safety on campus.
    Crime Reporting and Statistics: Provides crime statistics and information to the campus community and cooperates with other law enforcement agencies as needed.
    Collaboration with Campus Partners: Works closely with other campus departments, such as the Career Connections Center, Disability Resource Center, and Student Life, to ensure a safe and supportive campus environment.

Establishing a new center or institute at the University of Florida can contribute to public service in several ways. One of the primary ways is through the conduct of research in areas of public importance and the dissemination of knowledge gained from that research to the broader community. This can be achieved through collaborative research projects, seminars, and major conferences in the area of focus. The center or institute can also provide educational core or elective courses, fund graduate students, and offer core lab support for research of members. Additionally, the center or institute can mentor junior faculty, fund travel for students, and provide public programs and results of those programs.

Another way the new center or institute can contribute to public service is through fundraising accomplishments and exchanges, agreements, or planning initiatives. The center or institute can also aim to generate interdisciplinary resources, attract postdoctoral fellows, and create a lecture series. These activities can help address unmet needs and add value to the University that cannot be provided at the college, department, or division level.

The annual reports submitted by each UF Center/Institute to the Board of Governors will also be evaluated in the context of UF's mission of research, education, and service, and the strategic goals of the Florida Board of Governors. The evaluation will provide a brief critical review of the Center/Institute’s progress and an assessment of the return on investment of State dollars, if applicable. The Center/Institute should demonstrate how it adds value to the University that cannot be provided at the college, department, or division level.
The Florida Voluntary Prekindergarten Education Program (VPK) offers free pre-K education for all Florida 4-year-olds regardless of income.

Information sessions are an essential part of campus visits at the University of Florida. They are conducted by the Office of Admissions and are maintained at the Welcome Center next to the Reitz Union. These sessions provide visitors with valuable information about the university, including weekday and Saturday tours of the campus. Prospective students and their families can learn about academic programs, student life, and the various resources available to them at the University of Florida. For more information about visiting the campus, interested individuals can refer to the university's admissions website.

The UF Libraries offer several resources for students. In terms of study spaces, students can reserve study rooms and carrels. For research assistance, they provide research consulting services. They also offer a wide variety of take-home equipment rentals from tablets to DIY tools, and interlibrary loan services. Students can print for free on campus, and they also offer legal consultation and representation for certain types of cases, free notary services, and passport services. The libraries also engage the community by providing access to a free public library, a seed library, watt meters, meeting rooms, and many events, especially for families and kids. Additionally, they offer home energy tune-ups through the Community Weatherization Coalition. Repair stations are located across campus, though they aren't always working. Gainesville has several good bike shops. Student Nighttime Auxiliary Patrol (SNAP) offers a free nighttime shuttle van, and they provide energy-efficient lightbulbs, water saving attachments, and pipe insulation. Parking on campus may be limited during peak hours, and students can find additional transportation options on the TAPS website. The libraries also offer free access to high quality fresh local produce at farmers markets.

All students, faculty and staff have UFIDs, and the number is printed on the GatorOne card. More Info (https://dineoncampus.com/uf/ ) GatorLink | GatorOne Card | UFID GatorLink GatorLink establishes a unique computer identity for every student. More Info (http://helpdesk.ufl.edu/self-help/new-gator-resources/gatorlink/) All students must maintain and regularly check their GatorLink email as this is where all official university communications are sent. GatorOne Card The GatorOne card is the official university photo ID. The ID Card Services office is located on the ground floor of the UF Bookstore and Welcome Center complex on Museum Road.  More Info (https://businessservices.ufl.edu/services/gator-1-card/) All enrolled students, faculty and staff must have this card to: •Enter CIRCA computer labs, university libraries, the infirmary, recreation centers. •Sign up for intramural sports activities. •Participate in the textbook deferment program at the UF Bookstore. •Purchase tickets to university events. •Vote in Student Government elections. •Purchase food on campus with a Gator Dining or prepaid vending account. •Use as an ATM/debit card when activated through Wells Fargo Bank.  More Info (https://www.wellsfargo.com/student/banking/campuscard/) UFID UFID is an eight-digit number that serves as the primary identifier for all university records and transactions. Like a social security number, no two people will have the same number, and each person has only one. The UFID is assigned by the university, not chosen like a PIN. All students, faculty and staff have UFIDs, and the number is printed on the GatorOne card. FRESHMAN DATES & DEADLINES Keep this list of important dates so you do not miss a deadline. 2023-24 AUG8Application Opens August 8Prospective freshmen can apply using the Common Application.  NOV1Application Due November 1Applications must be received by UF Admissions no later than 11:59 p.m. EST on November 1 for consideration in the priority applicant round. Applications received after this date will be reviewed on a space-available basis, with a final deadline of March 1. NOV15Student Self-Reported Academic Record (SSAR) November 15If your SSAR is not received by the November 15 deadline, your application will be moved into the space-available applicant pool. DEC1Submit Official Test Scores December 1ACT or SAT scores may be sent directly from the testing agency or self-reported through your application status page. If your test scores are not received by the deadline, your application will be moved into the space-available applicant pool. Applicants who self-report scores and are admitted to UF must submit official test scores by December 1. FEB23Freshman Admissions Decisions February 23You can access your admissions decision via the Check Status application portal. Official written notifications of acceptance are mailed to admitted students only.  M AY1Confirm Enrollment May 1If you have been admitted into the freshman class and wish to enroll, confirm your intentions and pay your enrollment deposit no later than May 1 via your Check Status application portal. JUL15Send Official Transcripts July 15 If you are enrolling at UF, official transcript(s) for your high school and any colleges you have attended must be received by July 15 so that UF may finalize your enrollment.SEND YOUR TRANSCRIPTS TO:The UF Office of AdmissionsP. Work-Study jobs may be awarded by SFA to students with demonstrated financial need as part of an aid package. Other job programs, such as OPS employment, do not require financial need and are open to any student with the desire to work who meets the basic criteria of half-time enrollment and a 2.0 GPA. Student jobs usually are 15-20 hours a week and pay at least minimum wage.  More Info (http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/programs/employment/) Loans Loan programs include Federal Direct loans, Federal Direct Unsubsidized loans, Federal Direct PLUS loans, and UF institutional loans. These programs offer long-term, low-interest loans that must be repaid when the borrower graduates, withdraws, or drops to less than half-time enrollment. Parents of dependent undergraduate students can take out educational loans through the Federal Direct PLUS loan program.  More Info (http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/programs/loans/) When to Apply The Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FASFA) is available October 1 each year. Although SFA cannot award financial aid until students have been admitted to UF, they should apply for aid as soon as possible on or after October 1. •How to Apply for Financial Aid  (http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/applying/) •Enrollment Requirements for Financial Aid (http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/receiving/enrollment-requirements/) •How to Apply for Student Employment (http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/programs/employment/) Financial Aid Academic Progress Requirements UF students receiving financial aid are required to be in good standing and to maintain satisfactory academic progress.  More Info (http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/additional/academic-progress/) Recreational Sports With a vibrant student community and ample sunshine, campus life revolves around recreation. With fifty plus intramural and sport clubs, holistic wellness services, and its very own lakefront, UF RecSports is the premier destination for Gators seeking to get an active lifestyle. RecSports offers experiences that enrich the lives of University of Florida students through excellence in facilities, fitness, sport, adventure, and play. RecSports enhances the UF community by encouraging the development of the whole person, inspires self-discovery, and fosters a sense of belonging through inclusive recreational experiences. The review should  also include an assessment of the return on investment of State dollars, if applicable. The UFPD has the utmost concern for personal and property safety, but with an open campus environment, safety becomes a shared responsibility. The UFPD is a state of Florida and nationally accredited law enforcement agency. There are more than 90 fully certified and sworn officers who patrol the UF campus and its surrounding properties 24 hours per day, every day. The department has its own Criminal Investigations Division employing highly trained detectives to investigate any reported crime on campus. The officers of the Uniformed Patrol Division are highly trained campus law enforcement professionals who are equipped with the most contemporary crime-fighting techniques and tools. The Community Services Division is proactive in providing everyone in the campus community with the very latest information regarding personal and property protection through classes, programs and documents.  More Info (http://www.police.ufl.edu/) Map  (http://campusmap.ufl.edu/?loc=0027 ) Career Connections Center The Career Connections Center (C3) is the University of Florida’s comprehensive career services operation responsible for providing world class career and professional development for all students. As the # 2 Career Center in the country according to Best Colleges, the C3 prepares students for contributions in work, citizenship, and life. The center supports the overall student experience starting during Preview and moving beyond graduation. The C3’s mission is to educate and create connections for the University of Florida community to facilitate the holistic career development of students. The center provides a variety of services, tools, networks, and events for UF students and alumni. Whether exploring career options, developing professional skills, finding meaningful experience, or preparing for life after graduation, the C3 is there to help students on their unique journey. Through the university’s Career Pathways initiative, students can access customized information, connections, and programs to personalize their professional development experience and community. It's recommended that UF students engage early and often with the Career Connections Center to enhance their University of Florida experience and post-graduation success. Additional Reporting Requirements for University of Florida Centers/Institutes   In addition to the information submitted through the Expe rtnet system to the BOG, UF Centers /Institutes are required to provide annual reports as required by the Dean  of the College to whom they report.  The format and information required for these reports are specified by the Deans of the respective colleges.     VI. Guidelines for Evaluation of Centers and Institutes     The University administration will evaluate Centers/Institutes on a cyclical basis.  The Provost and Vice President for Research will evaluate each State of Fl orida Center/Institute every three (3) years.  Deans will evaluate the University of Florida Centers/Institutes assigned to their respective colleges every five (5) years.      The submission DEADLINE for all evaluations will be approximately April 15 of each year.  The Office of Institutional Planning and Research maintain s the schedule of evaluations of all Centers and Institutes, and will coordinate the process with the r espective deans and the office of the Vice President for Research.  Completed evaluations should be uploaded to the evaluation web site http://www.ir.ufl.edu/oirapps/centersandinstitutes/. (Please note, this differs from the annual reporting coordinated by the Office of Institutional Planning and Research).       Evaluations will focus on the mission and stated objec tives of the Center/Institute.  The evaluator should consider the following items as they evaluate their i ndividual Centers/Institutes. Additional

All three elemen ts are not required for a center to be established but should be identified when they are anticipated to be part of the mission.   D.  Proposed Activities: Describe the activities that are planned for the center (e.g., collaborative research on the topic of (X); the intent to generate interdisciplinary resources, to design courses, to develop an interdisciplinary graduate program, attract postdoctora l fellows, create a lecture series; to establish a core service facility, provide greater focus and depth to a r esearch area, etc.). Explain the plans to apply for external funding and identify the relationship of the center's activities with those of departments and/or other centers. Describe the advantages of the center over current structure (what unmet needs will be satisfied by having the center?) and the value of the center to the University and to the reporting unit. Describe, where possible, the synergistic and collaborative efforts existing amongst the members of the  proposed center.  Also describe their record in successfully garnering extramural funds.     E.   Reporting Structure: The proposal for a new cente r or institute must include a reporting structure and describe the logic of that structure at UF.  In particular, the proposal should outline to whom and through whom the center or institute reports.  The proposal s hould demonstrate appropriate levels of commitment and interest from relevant departments, colleges, or other stakeholders.     A new center or institute will in general, report to the dean of the college unless it is a campus-wide center or institute in which case it would report to th e relevant Vice President (Vice President Health Affairs, Vice President IFAS, Vice President for Research or the Provost ).  Any campus-wide centers should be discussed with the relevant vice president(s) prior to producing a proposal.  F.   Administrative structure: The position of the cente r/institute within the University/college/department must be explained with the lines of accountability and responsibility clearly indicated. Each center should design its own administrative structure in consultatio n with the relevant department chair(s) and dean. However, it is expected that each center/institute will have at a minimum, a director and an advisory committee.       4. Annual Reporting requirements to the Florida BOG (for All Centers /Institutes)      An annual report (July 1 through June 30) is to be subm itted for each Center/Institute. Financial aid can be awarded singly (one type of aid) or as a package.  More Info (http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/programs/) Grants Grants are awarded based on financial need. The largest grant program at UF is the Federal Pell Grant. Other grants include Federal Supplemental Educational Opportunity Grants, Teacher Education Assistance for College and Higher Education (TEACH) Grant, Florida Student Assistance Grants, UF Excellence Grant, UF Undergraduate Grant and UF Graduate Grants.  More Info (http://www.sfa.ufl.edu/programs/grants/) Scholarships Scholarships are awarded based on academic performance and /or financial need. Most scholarships are awarded through the SFA and individual UF colleges. SFA administers a limited number of scholarships from private donors. UF Centers and Institutes must be approved by th e relevant Dean(s), the relevant Vice President(s), the Vice President for Research, the Provost, and the President.  Because centers and institutes require a formal proposal process and review and approval by  the participating departments, the college and the offices of the Vice President for Research and Provost, only those entities that have gone through this process may call themselves a ‘center’ or ‘institute’. When more than one university is affiliated with a center/institute, the host university is  responsible for submitting a comprehensive report.    A. More Info (http://helpdesk.ufl.edu/self-help/new-gator-resources/gatorlink/) All students must maintain and regularly check their GatorLink email as this is where all official university communications are sent. GatorOne Card The GatorOne card is the official university photo ID. The ID Card Services office is located on the ground floor of the UF Bookstore and Welcome Center complex on Museum Road.  More Info (https://businessservices.ufl.edu/services/gator-1-card/) All enrolled students, faculty and staff must have this card to: •Enter CIRCA computer labs, university libraries, the infirmary, recreation centers. •Sign up for intramural sports activities. •Participate in the textbook deferment program at the UF Bookstore. •Purchase tickets to university events. •Vote in Student Government elections. •Purchase food on campus with a Gator Dining or prepaid vending account. •Use as an ATM/debit card when activated through Wells Fargo Bank.  More Info (https://www.wellsfargo.com/student/banking/campuscard/) UFID UFID is an eight-digit number that serves as the primary identifier for all university records and transactions. Like a social security number, no two people will have the same number, and each person has only one. The UFID is assigned by the university, not chosen like a PIN. All students, faculty and staff have UFIDs, and the number is printed on the GatorOne card.
